*Concentrated sputum smear microscopy*

*   A unique Liquefaction reagent
*   Separating any bacteria from the Mucin structures
*   Makes the staining of bacteria in sputum more sensitive
*   Easier for examination.
*   More Reliable results

<!-- Page 24 -->



# Fluorescent staining



## MATERIALS REQUIRED FOR STAINING
*   Auramine-Phenol solution
*   1% Acid alcohol
*   0.1% Potassium permanganate solution

A A P
(Handwritten notes, possibly signatures or initials, are present but illegible for precise transcription:
1.  © ELA
2.  © S. K. K. K.)

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



# STEPS

Place the slides on a staining rack, with the smeared side facing up, the slides not touching each other

Flood the slides with freshly filtered auramine-phenol. Let stand for 7-10 minutes

---

<!-- Page 26 -->



# STEPS

Wash well with running water, taking care to control the flow of water so as to prevent washing away the smear

Decolorize by covering completely with acid-alcohol for 2 minutes, twice

---

<!-- Page 27 -->



# STEPS

Wash well with running water, as before to wash away the acid alcohol

Counterstain with 0.1% potassium permanganate for 30 seconds

---

<!-- Page 28 -->



# Interpretation

| RNTCP ZN staining grading (using 100x oil immersion objective and 10x eye piece) | Reporting /Grading      | Auramine O fluorescent staining grading (using 20 or 25x objective and 10x eye piece) |
| :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :---------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| >10 AFB/field after examination of 20 fields                                      | Positive, 3+            | >100 AFB/field after examination of 20 fields                                         |
| 1-10 AFB/field after examination of 50 fields                                     | Positive, 2+            | 11-100 AFB/field after examination of 50 fields                                       |
| 10-99 AFB/100 field (~ 1 AFB/field)                                               | Positive, 1+            | 1-10 AFB/ field after examination of 100 fields                                       |
| 1-9 AFB/100 field                                                                 | doubtful positive /repeat | 1-3 AFB/100 fields                                                                    |
| No AFB per 100 fields                                                             | Negative                | No AFB per 100 fields                                                                 |

<!-- Page 30 -->



# Advantages - FM

*   More sensitive
*   Ideal for high volume laboratories
*   Detects low bacillary content
*   Diagnosis of TB in PLHIV (less TB load)
*   An increased contrast between stained bacilli & background
*   Superior technique (compared to ZN stain)

---

<!-- Page 31 -->



# Advantages - FM

*   Heating not required
*   Usage of low power objective
*   Immersion oil not needed
*   Covers an increased area of smear field
*   Less time consuming

---

<!-- Page 32 -->



# Disadvantages - FM

*   Initial high investment
*   Handling & maintenance of equipment
*   Skilled personnel
*   Continuous supply of power
*   Periodic replacement of bulbs
*   Can not differentiate species
*   Can not differentiate alive and dead
*   Cannot distinguish between drug resistant and drug-sensitive MTB
    *   (Handwritten note: All microscopy)

---

*   RAL STAINER
*   (RAL STAINER COLD ZN and FLUO RAL)
*   Automated staining station.
*   One Minute per slide
*   The product offers consistency of staining via automation
*   The machine can be used on all specimen types in laboratories
*   The Aerospray® TB Series 2 - process up to 400 slides per hour

# Automated Slide Reader system

*   To address difficulties in reading microscopy slides
*   TBDx system from Signature Mapping Medical Sciences Inc.
*   This system consists of
    *   FM with a digital camera
    *   Automatic slide loader (maximum capacity 200).
*   Stained slides are automatically loaded and viewed by the microscope

---

<!-- Page 37 -->



# Automated Slide Reader system

*   The digital images of each field per slide are then automatically processed by a proprietary algorithm.
*   The system takes approximately 5 minutes to analyse one slide, 1 hour to analyse 10–12 slides, or <u>16 hours to analyse</u> <u>200 slides.</u>
*   Data and results are in a format that can directly populate laboratory information systems.

# Mycobacterium Culture – Recent advances

*   Culture is the gold standard
*   Infrastructure
*   Biosafety Level 2 & 3 (solid culture, liquid culture)
*   Trained personnel

"Support bacteria. They're the only culture some people have."

**Badge:** The Gold Standard

---

<!-- Page 45 -->



# Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube (MGIT)

*   Modified Middle brook 9H11 medium (MMB 9H11)
*   Silicon film of ruthenium salt
*   Fluorescence indicator at the bottom
*   Turnaround time = 3 – 13 days [~2 weeks]
*   DST - Phenotypic

---

<!-- Page 46 -->

# Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube (MGIT)

*   If viable mycobacteria are present in the tube, oxygen is consumed due to their metabolism, the quenching effect lowers accordingly.

---

<!-- Page 47 -->



# Comparison of Solid & Liquid Culture

| Characteristics                   | LJ                                | Liquid cultures               |
| :-------------------------------- | :-------------------------------- | :---------------------------- |
| Speed in diagnosis                | 20 – 56 days (2 months)           | 7 – 14 days (rapid)           |
| Contamination                     | 2 – 3 %                           | 6 – 7 %                       |
| DST                               | First & second line               | First & second line           |
| Viability Tested                  | Yes                               | Yes                           |
| Isolation of NTM/Mixed cultures   | Rate of recovery limited          | Higher rate of recovery       |
| Skilled personnel                 | Required ✓                        | Not required                  |
| Cost                              | Economical                        | Expensive ✓                   |

Source: J.C.Palomino; Non conventional & New methods in the diagnosis of Tuberculosis: feasibility and applicability in the field.

<!-- Page 52 -->



# Real-time PCR

*   Rapid detection of MTb & drug resistance in TB.
*   Lower risk of contamination.
*   Directly to clinical samples/ Isolates
*   Results obtained in an average of 1.5 -2 hours after DNA extraction.
*   Expensive equipment and reagents ✓
*   Need for skilled technical personnel. ✓

---

<!-- Page 53 -->



# Genes responsible for Resistance

| Drug             | Genes responsible for resistance |
| :--------------- | :------------------------------- |
| Isoniazid        | katG, inhA, ahpC, oxyR, furA     |
| Rifampicin       | rpoB                             |
| Pyrazinamide     | pncA                             |
| Ethambutol       | embB                             |
| Fluoroquinolones | gyrA, gyrB                       |
| Streptomycin     | Rrs, rpsL                        |

---

<!-- Page 54 -->



# Real-time PCR protocol



## Real-Time PCR Protocol

1.  **Sample**
    *   Blood, Serum, Plasma, CSF, Pleural fluid, Ascites, Urine, Stool, Pus, Sputum, Swabs, Bronchial lavage, Tissue, FNAC etc.
2.  **DNA extraction**
3.  **Addition of premix reagents**
4.  **Automated amplification +**
    *   Detection
    *   Quantification
    *   Genotyping
    *   SNP
    *   Allelic discrimination
    *   Mutation detection

*   Fully integrating and automating RT PCR based
*   Three processes in a cartridge

Xpert™ MTB assay

1.  Add 2:1 Sample Buffer to sample
2.  Shake then stand 10 minutes
3.  Shake then stand further 5 minutes
4.  Transfer 2ml to cartridge

Begin Test...

# GeneXpert MTB/RIF

*   Major advantages in workflow
    *   No need of bio-safety cabinet
    *   Closed system (<u>no contamination risk</u>)
    *   One tube reaction & one step processing
    *   Specific for MTB, sensitivity close to culture
    *   Detection of Rif-resistance via rpoB gene
    *   Rapid detection (two hours)
    *   One day training for technologists

---

<!-- Page 59 -->



# TrueNAT

*   The Molbio Truelab™ RealTime micro PCR System
*   DNA extraction tool, amplification & detection instrument.
*   All are battery powered.
*   Test data can be printed from a battery powered printer

---

<!-- Page 60 -->



# GenoType MTBDR LipA
*Line probe assay*

*   Detects resistance to INH and RIF in culture samples
*   Common mutations in the katG and rpoB genes
*   Utilizes PCR and reverse hybridization to probes immobilized on a DNA strip
*   Turn around time – 6-8 hours

---

<!-- Page 61 -->



# Line Probe Assay –MTBDR Plus ASSAY

‡ Detects resistance to INH and RIF in culture samples
‡ Common mutations in - *katG* and *rpoB* genes
‡ 99 % of *rpoB* gene (RIF)
‡ 88.4 % *katG* gene (INH)
‡ Turn around time – 8 hours

Hillemann, 2005

# Phenotypic methods

*   Assess the inhibition of M. tuberculosis growth in the presence of antibiotics
*   Cultivation in egg-based or agar-based solid media
*   Simpler to perform
*   Implement on routine basis
*   Laborious
*   High turnaround time

# Detecting Latent Tuberculosis

## Current diagnostic tools * **Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)** * an immunological test based on DTH * **IFN-$\gamma$ release assays (IGRA)** * in vitro evaluation of cell-mediated immune response (effector memory cells) * QuantiFERON-TB Gold * QFT Gold in-Tube * QuantiFERON TB-2G * T-SPOT TB * **C-TB Skin Test** * ESAT-6 and CFP-10 ## Potential biomarkers * LTBI vs TB * Effect of drug therapy * Progression to active TB * **Targets** * **Cytokines and Chemokines** * IFN-$\gamma$, TNF-$\alpha$, IL-2, IL-7, CCL4, and CXCL10 * **T cell subsets** * CD4$^+$CD27$^+$PC-1$^+$ * CD4$^+$CD27$^+$CCR4$^+$ * Polyfunctional CD4T cells * CD4$^+$CD25 high CD39$^+$(Regulatory T cells) * **Genes** * IFN-inducible genes, ULK1, IFI44L, USP18, IFI44L * **MicroRNAs** * miRNA31, miR-150 miR-21, miR-29c, miRNA146a, miR-155 and miR-889 * **Antibody profiles** * immune response to "latency antigens" --- # Detecting Latent TB ## Product Information (Cy-Tb Injection) * **Product Name:** rdESAT-6 and rCFP-10 (Cy-Tb) Injection * **Usage:** For Intradermal Use * **Quantity:** 1 mL (10 Doses) x 50 Vials * **Test Dose:** 0.1 µg / 0.1 mL * **Manufacturer:** Serum Institute of India Pvt. sectionTitle: Immunology of TB in a Nutshell
content:
# Immunology of TB in a Nutshell

Inhalation of M. tuberculosis-infected aerosol
↓
Uptake by **macrophage** and **inhibition of phagolysosome formation**
↓
Presented to **CD4 T cells** → Secretion of **IFN gamma**
Macrophage activation → Epitheloid cell formation → TNF Alpha
↓
More **macrophage chemotaxis** → more Epitheloid cell formation
↓
Fusion of epitheloid cells → (Langhan cell) Giant cell formation
↓
**SOLID GRANULOMA FORMATION & CONTAINMENT**

---

**IFN-γ → maturation of the phagolysosome in infected macrophages, expression of inducible nitric oxide (NO) → killing of mycobacteria.**

---

Delayed Type Hypersensitivity
If macrophage-activating response is weak → DTH reactions & lung tissue destruction.
↓
At the center of the lesion, the **caseous material** (**lipid of cell membrane**) liquefies.
Invasion & Destruction of Bronchial walls & vessels → cavities are formed

---

<!-- Page 127 -->



# IMMUNE CELLS INVOLVED IN TB
A combination of both Innate and Acquired immunity acting in an orchestrated manner.

| INNATE IMMUNITY         | ACQUIRED IMMUNITY |
| :---------------------- | :---------------- |
| * Epithelial barriers   | * Th1 response    |
| * Phagocytic cells (Macrophages and Neutrophils). |                   |
| * Dendritic cells.      |                   |
| * Natural killer cells. |                   |

---

<!-- Page 128 -->



# INNATE IMMUNITY


## Functions in 3 stages
*   Recognition by Toll like Receptors [TLR] (checked)
*   Phagocytosis or engulfment of bacilli by mononuclear cells (checked)
*   Phagolysosome Fusion (crossed out)

---

<!-- Page 129 -->



# Entry mechanism of M.tb – THE BEGINNING



## Uptake of M. tuberculosis

1.  **Complement receptors**
2.  **Mannose receptor**
3.  **Scavenger receptors**

Phagosome
TLRs



## Phagocytosis –

*   Phagocytosis of M.Tb by alveolar **macrophages** and dendritic cells.
*   Engulfment of **opsonized bacilli** (which has preformed humoral elements like antibodies and complement split products) by **Complement receptors (CR 1,2,3,4)**
*   Engulfment of **non opsonized bacilli** (has terminal mannose moieties) through **mannose receptors**
*   Other receptors which play an important role in bacterial binding are **CD14 receptor and scavenger receptor type A.**

---

<!-- Page 130 -->



# Entry mechanism of M.tb – THE BEGINNING



## Uptake of M. tuberculosis

1.  Complement receptors
2.  Mannose receptor
3.  Scavenger receptors

Phagosome
TLRs



## Phagocytosis –

*   Phagocytosis of M.Tb by alveolar **macrophages** and dendritic cells.
*   Engulfment of **opsonized bacilli** (which has preformed humoral elements like antibodies and complement split products) by **Complement receptors (CR 1,2,3,4)**
*   Engulfment of **non opsonized bacilli** ( has terminal mannose moieties) through **mannose receptors**
*   Other receptors which play an important role in bacterial binding are **CD14 receptor** and **scavenger receptor type A.**

---

<!-- Page 131 -->



# PHAGOLYSOSOME FUSION INHIBITION: THE GREAT ESCAPE

*   If this phagolysosome fusion is prevented, Mtb survives inside the macrophages.
*   Mechanisms
    *   ① Inhibiting the maturation of Phagosome.
    *   ② Inhibiting the calcium signals leading to ineffective Phagosome-lysosome fusion.

---

**Diagrams:**

**Nonpathogenic bacterium**
*   **A**
    *   Early endosome
    *   Sphingosine kinase
    *   Phospholipase C
    *   EARLY PHAGOSOME
    *   Ca$^{2+}$ (+)
    *   Late endosome/lysosome
    *   Destruction (handwritten)
    *   PHAGOLYSOSOME

**Pathogenic mycobacterium**
*   **B**
    *   TB (handwritten)
    *   X (no fusion)
*   **C**
    *   Coronin 1
    *   Ca$^{2+}$
    *   Calcineurin (-)
    *   X (no fusion)

---

<!-- Page 132 -->



# ACQUIRED IMMUNITY:
? THE RESCUER

*   Macrophages express MHC II and display the bacterial antigen → Th1 response activated
*   IL-12 produced by APC's leads to differentiation of T - lymphocytes.
*   Th1 produces IFN-γ - THE CRITICAL MEDIATOR.
*   These response happens 2-8 weeks after infection

---

**Diagram Notes:**

*   **Top Diagram:**
    *   (Macrophage-like cell) --MHC II--> (T cell)
    *   IL12 (from Macrophage-like cell)
    *   (T cell) ↓ TH2 response
    *   ↓ IFNγ
*   **Bottom Diagram:**
    *   PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor (blocking interaction)
    *   (T cell) -- PD-1 -- PD-L1 -- (TB-infected Macrophage)
    *   (T cell) -- TCR MHC complex -- (TB-infected Macrophage)
    *   Inside TB-infected Macrophage: (bacteria)

---

<!-- Page 133 -->



# IFN - γ : THE TERMINATOR

- IFN-G
  - Stimulates **maturation** of **phagolysosome**
- IFN-G
  - Stimulates expression of **iNOS** leads to production of NO.
  - NO combines with other oxidants to form **RNI** (**Reactive nitrogen Intermediates**)
- IFN-G
  - Mobilises antimicrobial peptides.
  - Stimulates autophagy.

---

<!-- Page 134 -->

TNFα = ~~~~~~ 8888



# GRANULOMATOUS INFLAMMATION


## : DAMAGE CONTROL

*   Th1 response also leads to formation of granuloma and caseous necrosis.
*   Activated macrophages – differentiate into "Epitheloid Histiocytes".
*   Activated macrophages – secrete TNF α and other chemokines → Recruitment of monocytes and lymphocytes.
*   These Epitheloid cells fuse to form giant cells & granulomas.

---

<!-- Page 135 -->



# PROGRESSION OF DISEASE

*   In individuals with immune deficits, → the infection progresses and the ongoing immune response results in caseation necrosis.
*   Defects in any of the steps of a TH1 T cell response (including IL-12, IFN-γ, TNF, or nitric oxide production) result in poorly formed granulomas, absence of resistance, and disease progression.
*   Reactivation of the infection or reexposure to the bacilli in a previously sensitized host results in rapid mobilization of a defensive reaction but also increased tissue necrosis.

---

<!-- Page 136 -->



# GRANULOMA

*   Necrotic granulomas are structured around a central core of necrotic cell debris in which much of the bacteria are concentrated.
*   Fully formed tuberculous granuloma consists of a central zone of caseating necrosis, surrounded by cellular infiltrate comprising activated macrophages (epithelioid cells), DCs, T-lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and fibroblasts.
*   Macrophages are centrally located and have the ability to differentiate into multinucleated giant cells.

<!-- Page 139 -->



# Specific roles of immune cells in tb immunity

1.  CD4+ T cells : (IFNγ)
    *   Carry out **Apoptosis** of infected macrophages through Fas/Fas ligand interaction, production of cytokines like **IL-12** (✓), **TNF-α** (✓).
    *   Critical for the cytotoxic function of **CD8+ T cells** (✓), mediated by **IL-15** (✓).
    *   Control the **intracellular** (✓) growth of M.Tb via production of **RNI** (✓)\*.

2.  CD8+ T cells :
    *   Can directly (kill M.Tb) (✓) via **granulysin*** - controls both acute as well as chronic infection.
    *   Have role in *control of latent infection*, supported by reactivation of latent infection following *depletion of CD8+ T cells* (✓).

---

<!-- Page 140 -->



# REGULATORY T-CELLS [new]

Treg cells : prevent autoimmunity reduce excess tissue destruction but may also permit persistence of chronic infections
Regulatory T cells are mainly involved in suppression of host immunity.
? Mtb may induce expansion of Treg cells → delay onset of immunity and may permit replication

---

<!-- Page 141 -->



# CYTOKINES

- L
  - x TH1, TB
    - ↓ Infective

    - ↓ Allergic

*Main content:*
- Protective cytokines are **TNF alpha, IFN gamma, IL - 12,**
- Negative influence on immune response - **IL-4, IL-5, IL-10, TGF-B.** (TH2 influence)
- IL 12 : Under influence of **IL12, CD4 cells produce : TNF alpha, IFN gamma,**
- INTERLEUKIN - **4** responsible for suppression of Th 1 type of response (suppress the production of **IFN gamma**) and **thus host fails to contain the disease, leading to development of severe and disseminated forms of TB.**
- TGF β produced by monocytes & dendritic cells can suppress **CMI**, **INVOLVED IN TISSUE DAMAGE AND FIBROSIS**

- (Asterisk) IL4 TGFβ ↓ CMI

sectionTitle: Evasion of host immune response by m.tb
content:
# Evasion of host immune response by m.tb

1.  ✓ Modulation of antigen presentation to avoid elimination by T cells: The **ManLAM, trehalose 6,6'.** dimycolate (TDM, also known as _cord factor_), regulate IFN-✓γ inducible genes including those involved in antigen presentation by _MHC class II machinery_.
2.  ✓ _Superoxide dismutase and catalase_ secreted by bacilli are _antagonistic to ROI (reactive oxygen intermediates)_.
3.  Mycobacterial components such as **sulphatides, LAM,** and phenolic-glycolipid (PGLI) are **potent oxygen radical scavengers.**
4.  **Defective T-cell proliferation** DUE TO **cytokines, including TGF-B, IL-10 or IL-6.**
    *   _DCMI_ (handwritten below TGF-B)
5.  Mycobacteria are able to produce **ammonia** and **sulphatides** which **inhibit fusion of phagosomes with lysosomes.**

---

<!-- Page 143 -->



# OTHER FACTORS

**Brake protein PD1**
(Tcell) X X --C-- PD1
(Tumor) TD --C-- PDL1
T programmed cell death receptor binding ligand.
Doesn't allow T-cells to work properly.

**TNF alpha inhibition** increases chance of **TB reactivation**, as it controls production and **signaling in monocytes** for controlling MTB replication

**PDL1**-Programmed death receptor expression- modulates gene expression and to **shift antigenic expression** during overt replication and latency

✓ **ESAT-6** & **Ag85B genes** represents major **antigenic targets** for **CD4** And **CD8 cells**

\* NRAMP 1

# NATURAL H/O TB

Most primary tuberculous infections heal spontaneously
In some patients there may be sequelae to the primary
tuberculous infection and, in general, these tend to conform to a
'timetable of tuberculosis'
Wallgren described this timetable in Sweden in 1948 in the era
before chemotherapy or BCG when the majority of cases of
tuberculosis occurred in the young

---

<!-- Page 148 -->



# Walgreens time table

*   **1-2 months**: Primary complex tuberculin positivity
*   **3-6 months**: Miliary & meningeal TB 3→m
*   **6-12 months**: Pleural involvement (Pleural effusion due to seeding of the pleura from a lung focus)
*   **1-2 years**: cavitation (In young adults the primary disease could progress, with increasing infiltration and cavitation → progressive primary disease )
*   **1-5 years**: bone & joint TB
*   **5-15 years**: Genitourinary TB

---

    *   Crofton

*   **Early Dissemination**
    *   Miliary and meningeal tuberculosis common in children under 5 years; pleural effusion rare in children.
    *   Usually within 6-12 months after primary infection.
    *   (Diagram shows miliary pattern in lungs and brain involvement)

        *   3-6 months

*   **Post-Primary / Adult Disease**

    *   (Diagram shows cavitary lesions in lungs and spine involvement)
    *   Timeframes:
        *   1-2 Years

# Symptoms and signs of primary pulmonary Tuberculosis

*   **Asymptomatic:** A great majority especially adults \* (Noninfective)
*   **Brief febrile illness:** At the time of tuberculin conversion
*   **Anorexia, failure to gain weight:** In few cases with more severe infection or low host resistance
*   **Cough:** If LN or granulation tissue impinge on bronchial wall
*   **Sputum:** Rare in children
*   **Hypersensitivity phenomenon:** Erythema nodosum, phlyctenular conjunctivitis

# Special names of TB-foci in various organs

*   Ranke complex: fibrosed & calcified ghon's complex

*   Simon foci: subpleural focus in upperlobe during hematogenous spread & healing with scarring [healed foci]

*   Rich focus: cortical TB granuloma
*   Simmond focus: liver focus
*   Medler focus: kidney focus

# HOST BIOMARKERS FOR TUBERCULOSIS

Identification of clinically relevant biomarkers is required for better diagnosis, treatment and prevention of TB.

Hence biomarkers indicating disease status would boost development of better drugs, vaccines and diagnostics.

IL-6, IL-10, TNF alpha are most promising markers for active TB, while FOX P3, IL-4, IL-12 are most promising biomarkers for immunological correlates of protection.

FOX P3 T regulatory cells are an important predictive biomarker for MDR TB and chemotherapy.

PD-1 T cells is an useful biomarker to monitor treatment outcomes.

# FEVER DEFINITION & MECHANISM

-   **Fever**: Elevation of body temperature > 37.2°C/98.9°F in the morning and > 37.7°C/99.9°F in the evening)

Temp: 36.8° ± 0.4°C (98.2° ± 0.7°F), (lower in a.m., higher in p.m.)



## Mechanism

**Heat production** muscle and liver
**Heat dissipation** from skin & lungs



### Pathway

1.  Infections
2.  LPS (G-ve organism)
3.  Monocyte activation
4.  Pyrogenic cytokines: IL-1, TNFα, IL-6 (IL1 IL6 TNFα)
5.  Circulation
6.  Endothelium of the hypothalamus
7.  PGE₂
8.  Hypothalamic thermoregulatory center (Neurotransmitters, cAMP)
9.  Elevated set-point
10. Peripheral heat responses (conservation/production)
11. Fever



### Associated Symptoms

↑↑ prostaglandin E2 → myalgias and arthralgias



### Fever Events

Heat production (e.g., shivering, ↑ hepatic thermogenesis) → ↑ body temperature to the new set point.
When the set point is lowered again by resolution or treatment of fever, processes of heat loss (e.g., peripheral vasodilation and sweating) commence.

# WEIGHT LOSS [Involuntary]

*   Loss of 5% of body weight over 6-12 months * *significant wt loss*
*   The predominant biochemical source of wasting is increase in *tumor necrosis factor-alpha*, which causes a *net catabolic state*.
*   The physiologic basis of Tuberculosis associated wasting is poorly understood.
*   There are conflicting reports regarding the role of other hormones such as *ghrelin* and a recent study suggests that *plasma peptide YY* may modulate appetite suppression and be associated with poor prognosis in Tuberculosis patients.
    *   *Handwritten summary: Ghrelin plasma peptide YY appetite suppression*

# Haemoptysis

*   Haemoptysis can occur at **any stage** of **pulmonary tuberculosis**
    *   *even healed disease can cause*
*   Pathogenesis: / mechanism
    *   *even healed disease can cause*
*   Aneurysmal dilatation of **blood vessels** in walls of tuberculous cavities
*   Wall of tuberculous cavities have **dilated bronchial arteries**
    *   *=> Rupture*
    *   *(cavity can erode blood vessel)*
*   MC source: **Bronchial artery** *(d/t High pressure circulation)*
*   Massive hemoptysis => **> 100-150ml blood /episode** **OR > 400-600ml /day**
*   Mcc of death in massive hemoptysis: **Asphyxiation c̄ blood clot**
*   Most important in management of massive hemoptysis: **Airway maintenance**

---

<!-- Page 177 -->

# RASMUSSEN ANEURYSM

*   It is a Rare phenomenon caused by weakening of Pulmonary artery\* wall from adjacent cavitary tuberculosis. (low pressure vessel)
*   Progressive weakening of arterial wall occurs as granulation tissue replaces both adventitia and the media.
*   The granulation tissue in the vessel is replaced by fibrin → in thinning of arterial wall, pseudoaneurysm formation and subsequent rupture → Massive hemoptysis
*   Rx : Embolisation (Blocking localised branch of PA)

# Management

Massive hemoptysis
*   Stabilize pt
    *   Airway $\Rightarrow$ Intubation [Single lung vent by using Double lumen tube]
    *   Breathing
    *   Circulation
*   Protect healthy lung by placing bleeding lung down
*   Bronchoscopy [Rigid] + Tamponade of bleed [fogarty ballm]
    *   Adv:- Big suction channel. Easy to remove clod.
    *   $\rightarrow$ Has a ventilation port $\rightarrow$ so better control of Airway.
*   Bronchial Artery Embolisation
*   If localised disease $\Rightarrow$ Surgical resectm

Cavitations are hall mark and seen in both active and inactive disease that may disappear after ATT

Occasionally the wall becomes thin and remains air filled cystic space even after bacteriological cure then it is called open negative syndrome

# Mycetoma/aspergilloma

It is a mass of fungal hyphal material that grows in lung cavity: mc $\rightarrow$ *Aspergillus*
Other fungi like *zygomycetes* and *fusarium* may cause fungal ball
Also seen in cavities of *sarcoidosis*, bullae, neoplasms, histoplasmosis, bronchiectatic areas, bronchial cysts, bullae
Most pts are asymptomatic.
Symptoms: Hemoptysis, cough
Due to movement of fungus in cavity & damage to capillaries

# End stage lung destruction
(Non viable lung / Destroyed lung)

*   Both parenchymal and airway involvement
*   Occur after progressive primary or post primary infection
*   \*Cicatricial atelectasis is common finding after post primary tb
*   Reduced lung volumes, cavities, bronchiectasis and fibrosis are predominant findings opposite lung shows hyper inflation
*   They present with chronic cough and dyspnea may lead to chronic respiratory insufficiency and corpulmonale

# Broncholithiasis
(LN)

*   Presence of calcified/ossified (lymph node) masses within bronchi
*   Caused by erosion and extrusion of (calcified LN) into bronchial lumen
*   Symptoms may include cough hemoptysis lithoptysis or recurrent pneumonia
*   CT : calcified lymph node that is endobronchial or peri bronchial in location causing atelectasis or obstructive pneumonia or bronchiectasis
*   Symptomatic broncholiths should be removed at thoracotomy by lobectomy or segmentectomy \*

<!-- Page 191 -->



# COPD In pulmonary tuberculosis



## Mechanism:
*   *Pulmonary* cavities may obliterate or distort *airway* leads to obstruction
*   Lung parenchymal *inflammation* in tuberculosis may lead to *destruction* of the pulmonary *extra-cellular matrix (ECM)*, a feature similar to that of *COPD*.
*   *Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs)* are involved in the *pathogenesis* of both *TB* and *COPD* by *degrading components of ECM*
*   Prognosis is bad if *obstructive air way disease is severe*

COPD I: Infection related [Post TB]



## Flowchart: Mechanisms of airflow obstruction due to tuberculosis
1.  TUBERCULOSIS
2.  Leads to increased MMPs (Matrix metalloproteinases) secretion
3.  Leads to Destruction of extracellular matrix
4.  Leads to Chronic airflow obstruction

FIGURE 1 is showing the mechanisms of airflow obstruction due to tuberculosis

<!-- Page 199 -->

Cor pulmonale in pulmonary tuberculosis

Mechanism
* Extensive fibrosis, distortion of pulmonary vascular bed cavities, repeated infections, insufficient pul reserve $\rightarrow$
  Hypoxemia $\Rightarrow$ Pul.vasoconst [mediated by K$^+$ channels]
  *Hypoxia - Sensitive K$^+$ channels
  Pul. HTN $\Rightarrow$ Rv dysfunction

# Chronic respiratory failure

Delays in diagnosis and treatment of tb can lead to structural changes like bronchovascular distortion, bronchiectasis, emphysema and fibrosis → ventilation perfusion mismatch causing chronic hypoxia and respiratory failure

# Secondary amyloidosis

TB is the commonest underlying cause for renal amyloidosis \*

IL1, IL6, TNF α → ↑ Amyloid synthesis by liver & excess deposition in various organs

Renal amyloidosis → Nephrotic synd
→ Proteinuria
↘ Pedal edema

wide spread inflammatory reaction + obliterative
endarteritis $\rightarrow$ damage to alveolar capillary membrane

in pathogenesis ( Activation of macrophage & release of
TNF, IL1 $\rightarrow$ Lung injury) cxr: B/L diffuse opacities

Pts present with hypoxemia that is refractory to oxygen
supplementation

*   After any intervention (chest tube, etc.) In evaluation of symptomatic patients with suspected TB sequelae: when no prior radiographs available for comparison or if evolution of new findings
*   In evaluation of symptomatic patients (e.g hemoptysis, dyspnea, cough with expectoration) with past history of TB

# WHY MULTI DRUG THERAPY ????

The letters in the quadrants represent the first-line drugs used in Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for Tuberculosis:

*   **H**: Isoniazid
*   **R**: Rifampicin
*   **Z**: Pyrazinamide
*   **E**: Ethambutol

<!-- Page 243 -->



# THE BASIS



## Initial Intensive phase (IP) 2 months :

In an untreated TB patient, there are naturally occurring drug resistant mutants.
For example occurrence of drug resistant mutants would be roughly ~1 in 10⁶ to isoniazid (H) that are capable of multiplying and will not be affected by a single isoniazid → frequent failures observed with monotherapy of patients.
If two or more drugs are given concurrently, in the initial Intensive Phase when the bacterial load is high, the chances of survival and selection of drug resistant organism will be low as mutants resistant to one drug may be susceptible to other



## Role of continuation phase (CP) 4 months :

fewer drugs for a comparatively longer time will ensure elimination of persisters which are responsible for relapses.

# Pyrazinamide

*Bactericidal*



## Mechanism of Action
*   pyrazinamide to pyrazinoic acid (pncA gene)
*   mycolic acid, disrupt mycobacterial cell membrane and its transport function



## Activity
*   More active in acidic medium.
*   It is more lethal to intracellularly located bacilli and to those at sites showing an inflammatory response, probably because pH is acidic at both these locations.



## Metabolism
*   METABOLISM (Liver > Kidney)
*   No drug interaction (with the liver)



## Adverse Effects
*   Hepatotoxicity
*   Hyperuricemia
    *   arthralgias, anorexia, nausea and vomiting, dysuria, malaise, and fever



## Special Considerations
*   Hemodialysis removes pyrazinamide; therefore, the drug needs to be redosed after each session of hemodialysis.
*   Require dosage adjustment in pts with renal disease.

    *   Vision usually returns to normal within a few weeks if the drug is stopped, but the optic nerve may be permanently damaged if ethambutol is continued
    *   \* Supplement with Hydroxycobalamine( Vit B12) \*
    *   Hyperuricemia (Handwritten: Pyu Etham)

*   (Image of kidney)
    *   Require dosage adjustment in pts with renal disease

SECOND LINE ATT- MDR TB DRUGS - Group A
Fluoroquinolones
*   Structure- Derivatives of **pyridine carboxylic acid**
*   - intermediates of chloroquine synthesis
*   Absorption- GIT
*   Bioavailability- 100%
*   Metabolism- **hepatic**, excreted **unchanged**
*   in urine <48 hr
*   MOA- inhibits **DNA GYRASE**
*   Moxifloxacin = **gatifloxacin** (Removed from market) > **levofloxacin** > **oflaxacin** mg/kg
*   **Complete cross resistance** between the FQ drugs
*   Dose- 15 mg/kg body weight/ 750 mg-1g

Mechanism of action
(Diagram showing Topoisomerase acting on DNA, leading to DNA damage & ROS accumulation, which results in Bacterial death)

<!-- Page 298 -->

SECOND LINE ATT- MDR TB DRUGS-Group A
Flurouinolones

*   CVS - QTC Prolongation : ↓K+ Blockage of voltage gated K+ channels [HERG channels] in cardiac myocytes, delaying repolarisation.
*   Tenosynovitis : FQ's disrupt collagen synthesis & the MMP's which weakens tendons/approved sheath.
*   Photosensitivity : FQ's generate Reactive oxygen species.
*   Dysglycemia : FQ's (especially gatifloxacin) affect pancreatic β-cell function, altering insulin release. Lt hypo/hyperglycemia.
*   Liver injury : Like FQ's generate of toxic metabolites or idiosyncratic immune reactions, leading to hepatocellular injury or cholestasis.
*   Gastrointestinal : FQ's Alter Gut microbiota, disrupt normal motility & initiate GI upset causing nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, pain Abd.
*   CNS - Dizziness, mood changes, : FQ's penetrate BBB & Inhibit GABA-A receptors causes excitatory Effects like agitation, Anxiety, Insomnia, Seizures.
*   headache, rarely convulsions
*   Peripheral neuropathy : FQ's may cause oxidative stress & mitochondrial dysfunction in peripheral nerves. Lt sensory/motor axon damage, manifests as pain/tingling/numbness.

# SECOND LINE ATT- MDR TB DRUGS—Group B



## Clofazimine

*   **Class:** semi-synthetic riminophenazine
*   **MOA:** disrupt ETC electron transport chain generate ROS
    *   **Mechanism A (Disruption of ETC and ROS generation):** CFZ acts as an artificial electron acceptor, diminishing flow of electrons through the ETC, while redox cycling leads to production of intracellular ROS. CFZ interacts with NDH-2, leading to the production of ROS from O2, and conversion of NADH to NAD+ + H+.
    *   **Mechanism B (Membrane destabilization and Ion Transport Inhibition):**
        *   Inhibition of H$^+$ pump.
        *   Inhibition of K$^+$ uptake.
        *   Direct membrane destabilization.
        *   Stimulatory effect on PLA$_2$ activity, which acts on membrane phospholipids to produce lysophospholipids.
    *   **Overall effect:** Both mechanisms lead to disruption of ATP production in *M. tuberculosis bacillus*.
*   **Pharmacokinetics:** If taken with food increases absorption, orally active, accumulates in tissues- fat
*   **Hepatic metabolism**
*   **Dose:** 100 mg daily
    *   *Handwritten note:* C = 100

## TB - HIV: THE RELATIONSHIP

*(Handwritten notes near title: CD4 -> TB, HIV <- CD4, HIV <- MΦ -> TB)*

### Vicious Cycle Flowchart Elements:

*   Worsening immuno-suppression in PLHIV
*   Decreased IFN-γ T_H1 lymphocytes *(Handwritten: 2)*
*   Mycobacterium tuberculosis clinical disease
*   AIDS *(Handwritten: 1)*
*   Increased viral replication
*   Macrophage cytokine production (IL-1, 6 & TNF)
    *   *(Handwritten notes below: TB -> macrophage activation, cytokine coil, increase of HIV replication)*

### EFFECT OF HIV ON TB

*   HIV induces TB through killing of CD4 T cells within granulomas
*   HIV manipulation of macrophage function prevents M.TB killing
*   Functional disruption of local immune response in granuloma

### EFFECT OF TB on HIV

*   ? Immune activation due to TB may increase proportion of CD4 cells that are targets of HIV
*   Greater HIV replication in stimulated macrophage infected with M.TB observed
    *   *(Handwritten notes below: TB MΦ infection, HIV replication inside)*

DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACR

# TB HIV

*   In early stages pulmonary TB presents in a typical manner [Like in UB]
*   In late stages : a primary TB-like pattern with interstitial infiltrates, little or no cavitation, pleural effusion, and intrathoracic lymphadenopathy, LN TB, CNS TB etc $\rightarrow$ Disseminated Everywhere

All asymptomatic HIV patients and those, in whom active TB is ruled out, should be offered Isoniazid Preventive Therapy (IPT) for six months.

In TB HIV Co infection :
*   If ART Started first there is risk of Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS)
*   Start ATT first and merge ART with 2 weeks to 2 months

sectionTitle: Among PLHIV with TB meningitis, ART should be dela
content:
Among PLHIV with TB meningitis, ART should be delayed for at least 4 weeks (and initiated within 8 weeks) after treatment for TB meningitis is initiated.
Corticosteroids should be considered as adjuvant treatment for TB meningitis.

Appropriate ART regimen

"WHO Consolidated Guidelines on HIV Prevention, Testing, Treatment, Service Delivery and Monitoring, July 2021

sectionTitle: ART Regimen in PLHIV Receiving First-line (Rifampicin-containing) anti TB treatment
content:
# ART Regimen in PLHIV Receiving First-line (Rifampicin-containing) anti TB treatment
*Most common* [DSTB]

TB + HIV



## Scenario 1: (HIV Pts in general)

Tenofovir, lamivudine and Dolutegravir (TLD) is the preferred regimen for all PLHIV

* The first line (Rifampicin-containing) ATT can be used with Double-dosing DTG
  * 2HRZG + 4HRG
  * *Because Rifampicin is given?*

* TDF 300 mg (*Tenoform*) + 3TC 300 mg (*Lami*) + DTG 50 mg at bedtime +(DTG 50 mg) in the morning to be given for the entire duration of ATT

✓ DTG 50mg to be continued till 2 weeks after completion of Rifampicin-containing anti-TB treatment

DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 336 -->



# ART Regimen in PLHIV Receiving First-line (Rifampicin-containing) anti TB treatment



## Scenario 2
Women of childbearing potential who do not wish to take DTG-based ART
*   Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Efavirenz (600mg)
*   ATT: 2HRZE + 4HRE



## Scenario 3
If Efavirenz is contraindicated (HIV-2/HIV-1&2/prior NNRTI exposure)
*   Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + [Lopinavir (200 mg) + ritonavir (50 mg) twice daily]
*   Rifampicin must be replaced with Rifabutin 150 mg in anti-TB treatment regimen

---

<!-- Page 337 -->

(HIV ART → OPD)


# Management recommendations for TB diagnosed in patients already receiving ART

1.  On **TLD Regimen**
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen
    Double dosing of **Dolutegravir** \*

2.  On **TLE regimen**
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen

On **TL + PI regimen** (Tenofovir, Lamivudine + PI)
*   (a) (If possible, give TLD) Consider changing to DTG-based regimen if patient has not received or not failed on DTG
    -> ATT: **2HRZE** + **4HRE** daily regimen
*   (b) ART: If the same **PI-containing** regimen has to be continued
    -> ATT: **Rifampicin** must be replaced with **Rifabutin 150 mg** in anti-TB treatment regimen

**PI*** + DTG
*   Double dosing of **Dolutegravir 50 mg** to be given for the entire duration of anti-TB treatment and **not beyond** (since patient had Rifabutin) ✓\*
    -> ATT: **Rifampicin** must be replaced with **Rifabutin 150 mg** in anti-TB treatment regimen

PI=Lopinavir/r, Darunavir/r, Atazanavir

---

<!-- Page 338 -->



# ART for TB-HIV Co-infected Patients on Bedaquiline or Delamanid

*   (TLD *) DTG-based regimen should be the ART regimen of choice for PLHIV on Bedaquiline / Delamanid-containing DR-TB regimens. Dolutegravir can be used safely and at the usual dose.
*   (✓) If PLHIV are already on NRTI + DTG regimen (TLD), the same is to be continued with BDQ/DLM containing DR-TB regimen (→ DTG).
*   (✓) If PLHIV is on NNRTI/PI-based ART regimen, a DTG-based ART regimen must be used when co-prescribing with BDQ/DLM containing DRTB regimens due to drug-drug interactions. (X PI X BDQ/DLM [non] concomitant)
*   (℗) TB-HIV co-infected PLHIV requiring a PI-based second-/third-line ART need coordination between SACEP (great A.D. clinical expert panel) and the linked DR-TB centre for considering a non-BDQ/DLM DR-TB regimen. (PI + BDQ/DLM => Intensive monitoring, need to be given)
*   (✓) In case an effective DR-TB regimen cannot be made without Bedaquiline/ Delamanid, the necessary DR-TB regimens using new TB drugs may be given with PI-based ART but with intensive monitoring for toxicities of Bedaquiline/ Delamanid.
*   (✓) PLHIV on ARV regimens with boosted PI, if treated with Bedaquiline-based ATT, should be monitored closely.
*   (Ⓝo) No dose adjustments are needed when Delamanid is used with Tenofovir, Efavirenz and Lopinavir/Ritonavir., but more frequent ECG monitoring is advised (TLER).

---

<!-- Page 339 -->

PT WITH HIV DEVELOPING TB
In a nutshell



## OLD REGIMEN X DRTB

*   Tenofovir, lamivudine and Efavirenz ✔
*   Tenofovir, Lamivudine & Nevirapine / Protease Inhibitor ✔

**DS TB**: In efavirenz ART Regimen Rifampicin can be given.
In Nevirapine / PI based regimen Rifabutin used in place of rifampicin.
**DR TB**: Efavirenz PI and BDQ DRUG INTERACTIONS (close monitoring)



## NEW REGIMEN

*   Tenofovir, lamivudine and Dolutegravir (NEW) (TLD)

**DS TB**: Double-dosing DTG in combination with rifampicin-containing ATT ✔
**DR TB**: Dolutegravir can be safely given with BDQ / DLM in DR TB ✔

H, R, Z, Bdq, Eto, PAS and and rarely FQ.
*short MDR drugs*

In patients with pre-existing liver disease with persistently abnormal liver function test, a shorter oral MDR/RR-TB regimen will be avoided due to presence of H(h), Eto and Z.

Safe in liver disease

*   Cycloserine (CS)

*Acc - EF_L*

<!-- Page 342 -->



# CHILD PUGH SCORE

| Clinical and Lab Criteria | Points* 1 | Points* 2 | Points* 3 |
| :------------------------ | :-------- | :-------- | :-------- |
| Encephalopathy            | None      | Mild to moderate (grade 1 or 2) | Severe (grade 3 or 4) |
| Ascites                   | None      | Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive) | Severe (diuretic refractory) |
| Bilirubin (mg/dL)         | < 2       | 2-3       | > 3       |
| Albumin (g/dL)            | > 3.5     | 2.8-3.5   | < 2.8     |
| Prothrombin time: Seconds prolonged | < 4       | 4-6       | > 6       |
| Prothrombin time: International normalized ratio | < 1.7     | 1.7-2.3   | > 2.3     |

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class obtained by adding score for each parameter (total points)
Class A = 5 to 6 points (least severe liver disease)
Class B = 7 to 9 points (moderately severe liver disease)
Class C = 10 to 15 points (most severe liver disease)

### Box 1 Grades of renal impairment in chronic kidney disease (CKD)

**Stage 1 CKD:** Normal creatinine clearance and function but urinary tract abnormality, for example, polycystic kidney, structural abnormality.
**Stage 2 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 60–90 ml/min
**Stage 3 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 30–60 ml/min
**Stage 4 CKD:** Creatinine clearance 15–30 ml/min
**Stage 5 CKD:** Creatinine clearance <15 ml/min with or without dialysis.

---

<!-- Page 347 -->



# PRACTICE POINTS

*   The practical method is to give the medications immediately following hemodialysis to avoid premature removal of Drugs and advantage of Directly observed Treatment.
*   In general, the doses of the anti-TB medications should not be reduced but rather the interval should be increased.

# PRESUMPTIVE TB

A Pt with any one of the following :

*   Fever > 2weeks

*   Hemoptysis
*   Significant wt loss

*   It refers to the patient who is eligible for rifampicin resistant screening at the time of diagnosis OR/and during followup
*   This includes :
    *   all notified TB patients,
    *   follow-up positive on microscopy including treatment failures on standard first-line treatment and H mono/poly DR-TB regimen and
    *   any clinical non-responder

RECURRENT CASE: A TB patient previously declared as successfully treated (cured/treatment completed) and is subsequently found to be microbiologically confirmed TB

LOSS TO FOLLOW UP (DS TB): A TB patient whose treatment was interrupted continuously for ONE month or more.

LOST TO FOLLOW-UP (DR TB): A patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more.

sectionTitle: WHICH IS BEST CBNAAT VS TRUENAT ??
content:
# WHICH IS BEST CBNAAT VS TRUENAT ?? CBNAAT | TRUENAT --- | --- | Study Title | Author/year | Place of study | Sample size | Type of study | Data reported (Sensitivity/specificity) | | :---------- | :---------- | :------------- | :---------- | :------------ | :------------------------------------ | | ICMR Study: Operational feasibility and performance of TrueNat MTB RIF assays in field settings under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program | Tripathi et al, 2019 | India | 10878 | Sensitivity/Specificity analysis | TrueNat: 84.1 (Sensitivity)
GeneXpert: 81.0% (Sensitivity) | | Evaluation of the Indian TrueNat micro RT-PCR device with GeneXpert for case detection of pulmonary tuberculosis | Nikam et al.2014 | Mumba | 247 | Observational | TrueNat: 99% (Sensitivity)
GeneXpert: 100% (Sensitivity) | # WHO PERFORMED BETTER FOR NAATU NAATU ? DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 15 --- # Firstline LPA, LC DST *Second Life* * **Line-probe assay** (**FLPA**, **SL LPA**): for rapid detection of drug resistance (**Rifampicin**, **Isoniazid**; **Fluoroquinolones**, **second-line injectable drugs**). * Performed directly on **AFB smear-positive** specimens or indirectly on culture isolates if the smear is negative. * DNA targets are amplified by **PCR** and hybridized to **immobilized oligonucleotide** targets; results can be read visually or using an automated reader. Turn around time : **1-3 days** ✓ * **Liquid Culture DST (LC DST)**: **BACTEC MGIT 960 TB system**\* *modified Middlebrook 9H11 medium.* * Turn around time : **8–10 days** for **smear positive samples** **2–6 weeks** for **smear negative samples** *(1½ month)* --- GUIDELINES FOR PROGRAMMATIC MANAGEMENT OF DRUG RESISTANT TB IN INDIA 2021 DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FAGI EDARM --- # XPERT ULTRA * In 2017, WHO recommended Xpert Ultra the next generation of Xpert MTB/RIF for diagnostic use * Uses the same GeneXpert platform * Developed to overcome the limitations of Xpert MTB/RIF * Imperfect sensitivity, particularly in smear negative and HIV-associated TB * Better determination of rifampicin resistance * Quantification into High, medium, low, very low and New "trace" category – corresponds to lowest bacillary burden World Health Organization. 2017. Next-generation Xpert MTB/RIF Ultra assay recommended by WHO. World Health Organization, Geneva, Switzerland. DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 17 --- # XPERT MTB / RIF VS XPERT ULTRA

# Conclusions...

Ultra is non-inferior to the Xpert MTB/RIF assay

Ultra has a higher sensitivity than Xpert MTB/RIF particularly in smear negative culture-positive specimens and in specimens from HIV-infected patients
*very low load of bacilli*

As a result of the increased sensitivity, Ultra also detects nonreplicating or non-viable bacilli present particularly in patients with recent history of TB, reducing the overall specificity of Ultra in high-burden TB setting

# WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING

*   NAAT and LPA may not detect clinically relevant mutations outside the rifampicin resistance determining region (RRDR) of the rpoB gene.
*   One such example is the I491F mutation that has been responsible for an outbreak of MDR-TB in Eswatini and remains a grave public health concern.

*   WGS provides a comprehensive review of the entire Mtb genotype with a 96% concordance for culture-based sensitivity testing.
*   It provides genotypic sensitivity to most drugs required for treatment of MDR-TB.
*   Can provide individual Pt centered DR TB Rx.

Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) is an isothermal PCR amplification technique that can be performed in peripheral health care settings.

Prepare lysate

# TB LAMP → Diagnosis not resistance

*   TB-LAMP may be used as a replacement test for sputum smear microscopy to diagnose pulmonary TB in adults with signs and symptoms consistent with TB (conditional recommendation, very low-quality evidence).
*   TB-LAMP should not replace the use of rapid molecular tests that detect TB and resistance to rifampicin. (only D/S not for resistance)
*   In settings where the Xpert MTB/RIF assay cannot be implemented TB-LAMP may be a plausible alternative.

*   Can be used as initial test in peripheries in areas of high TB endemicity only, to determine whether symptomatic patients with HIV should be referred for further confirmatory testing

# Cy TB / C tb

Cy-Tb (formerly known as the C-Tb test, Serum Institute of India) contains a 1:1 ratio of two recombinant proteins of ESAT-6 and CFP-10 was previously produced by genetically modified Lactobacillus lactis, by Statens Serum Institute (Denmark).

One single test dose of 0.1 mL contains 0.05 µg of rdESAT-6 and 0.05 µg of rCFP-10.

# C-tb / Cy-Tb

C-Tb is the next-generation skin test for detection of Tuberculosis.

*   Easy-to-use (Simple) / Point-of-care (On field) / Specific test (based on ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens of MTb)
*   C-Tb can become an excellent diagnostic test for management of latent TB due to its high specificity for detection of *M. tuberculosis* infection.
*   Unaffected by BCG vaccination status
*   Easy Replacement for PPD (TST) test Point-of-care (On field)
*   C-Tb combines the simplicity of the skin test with the diagnostic accuracy of the IGRA tests.
*   C-Tb has a similar sensitivity compared to TST and QFT in adults and children with active TB or presumed LTBI using a universal 5 mm cut-point. In HIV-infected persons C-Tb appeared more sensitive than QFT (Quantiferon TB Test)

sectionTitle: Target product profile for therapeutic vaccines / Immunotherapy
content:
# Target product profile for therapeutic vaccines / Immunotherapy

They should:

(1) $\downarrow$recurrence caused by drug-sensitive and resistant TB, following completion of a full course of drug therapy.
(2) $\uparrow$proportion of cured patients, in particular for rifampicin-resistant and extensively drug-resistant TB.
(3) Shorten therapy duration with the goal of improving compliance and reduce the likelihood of developing drug resistance.

Dated: 24th August, 2023

Dear Madam,

Warm Greetings from Central TB Division !!
I am hereby directed to inform that:

The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has planned to conduct the Adult TB Vaccination study titled "Effect of BCG vaccination among vulnerable adult population in reducing TB disease: a programmatic study" with the collaboration of National TB Elimination Programme, Immunization Division and ICMR institutes. 23 States/UTs have consented to participate in the study. Randomization of implementing districts and control from each State/UT for Adult BCG Vaccination has been completed by ICMR and is enclosed as Annexure-1.

2. D.O Letter No T-18012/08/2022-TB dated 25th April, 2023 regarding implementation of the Adult BCG Vaccination in a study mode in collaboration with ICMR was shared earlier along with the study protocol.

3. The Adult BCG Vaccination will be conducted in a Campaign mode similar to Mission Indradhanush as per the approved protocol in the intervention districts.

4. The States participating in the study will be provided trainings on the "Standard Operational Guidelines for Adult BCG Vaccination" with support from the Central TB Division and Immunization Division. The implementation will be done in a phased manner.

We request your support for smooth implementation of the Adult BCG Vaccination study.

This is issued with the approval of competent authority.

(Dr. Rajendra P. Joshi)

# Mycobacterial killed Whole-cell/fragmented vaccine

The entire pathogen that is either killed (inactivated) or weakened (attenuated) so that they cannot cause disease. They are known as the whole-organism vaccines.

pathogen
Killed
weakened
Live attenuated

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
52

---

<!-- Page 408 -->



# Mycobacterium vaccae

*   Heat-killed preparations of *M. vaccae* (MV or SRL72) have been extensively studied as adjuncts to standard anti-tuberculous drug therapy for more than decade.
*   It was hypothesized that inactivated MV works by stimulating the host immune responses to antigens shared with Mtb.
*   In addition to markers of cell-mediated immune stimulation, individuals treated with MV had increased antibody titers to the heat shock proteins HSP60 and HSP70 – which are known to be immunostimulatory – in the first month of treatment, as well as raised levels of the cytokines IL-4, IL-10 and TNF-α from ex vivo stimulated PBMCs with inactivated Mtb.

---

<!-- Page 409 -->

MV - V7
Of the therapeutic vaccines under consideration, MV is the most advanced in the clinical pipeline.
After the initial set of small scale studies, a single dose of intradermally delivered MV was felt to be insufficient for a robust clinical response, and trial protocols were modified to include multiple doses.
MV therapy was again associated with rapid sputum culture clearance of Mtb.
However, definitive evidence for MV in treatment outcome in large-scale studies is still awaited.

---

<!-- Page 410 -->



# Mycobacterium indicus pranii

*   MIP comprises **killed M. indicus pranii**, previously known as Mycobacterium w- non-pathogenic mycobacterium closely related to M. avium.
*   There is an ongoing **phase III efficacy and safety trial** for preventing pulmonary TB among healthy household contacts of sputum positive TB patients in India and first results are expected soon (**ICMR**).
*   In summary, **MIP** has shown robust evidence of **immune stimulation**.
*   Evidence of efficacy, however, is **still lacking** or awaited in either treatment, or prevention of active TB following high risk exposure.

---

<!-- Page 411 -->



# RUTI® for MDR-TB



# RUTI
(Handwritten note: : Detoxified liposomal fragments of MTB)

*   RUTI is composed of **liposomes** (highlighted) containing **detoxified fragments of Mtb** (underlined) that was cultured under conditions of hypoxia/stress that can induce **poly antigenic** (highlighted, handwritten ✓) cellular response against non-**replicating bacilli** (highlighted, handwritten ✗)
*   RUTI has improved efficacy against **non-replicating** (highlighted, handwritten ⭐) bacteria (NRB), that are hypothesized to contribute to the requirement of prolonged treatment, as well as relapse (circled).

(Handwritten note: RUTI - Rilepu Packaging)

(Handwritten checkmarks are also present on the red line and the dashed lines within the graph itself.)

---

<!-- Page 412 -->



# RUTI

In human studies, a combined phase I/II clinical trial was conducted to test the tolerability and immunogenicity of different RUTI doses in HIV positive and negative patients.

The results demonstrated that RUTI vaccination had reasonable tolerability profile of RUTI® and a good polyantigenic response in HIV- and HIV+ subjects.

---

<!-- Page 413 -->



# Live attenuated vaccines

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP PACI EDARM

<!-- Page 414 -->

VPM1002 (BCG ΔureC::hly)
_a recombinant BCG technology_

VPM1002 is a recombinant BCG (rBCG) in which the urease C gene has been replaced by the listeriolysin O (LLO) encoding gene (hly) from _Listeria monocytogenes_.

Generated in order to induce a broader immune response against mycobacterial antigens.

A phase II/III clinical trial with VPM1002 is currently ongoing in India to for the prevention of recurrence of active TB in adults following completion of standard therapy (NCT03152903).

Vakzine Projekt Management
Dr Bharath K.M.

---

<!-- Page 415 -->



# Subunit vaccines

This type of vaccine is constituted of a protein subunit of *Mtb*.

It contains just enough antigenic determinants that are necessary to stimulate a long-lasting protective immune response.



## The subunit approach

Only uses the very specific parts (the subunits) of a virus or bacterium that the immune system needs to recognize.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

H56:IC31 is a recombinant fusion protein
comprised of three Mtb antigens Ag85B, ESAT-6
and Rv2660c, formulated in IC31 adjuvant.

The H56:IC31 vaccine induced antigen-specific
IgG responses and Th1 cytokine-expressing
CD4(+) T cells.

---

<!-- Page 417 -->



# M72/AS01E

This vaccine is composed of:
*   Antigen: M72
*   Adjuvant: AS01E

Comprises a recombinant fusion protein of two Mtb-derived proteins, **Mtb32A** and **Mtb39A**; delivered with the adjuvant **AS01E**.

In a Phase **IIb** trial conducted in **HIV-ve** and **IGRA+ve pts**, the efficacy of the vaccine was proved to be around **50%**.

Although the mechanisms of protection are not known, both **CD4+ T cell** and **antibody responses** were associated with **protection**.

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and Aeras.

---

<!-- Page 418 -->

# Viral vectored vaccines

*   This type of vaccine uses live viruses to carry recombinant DNA molecules that encode the antigenic proteins of Mtb. Transfer of this recombinant DNA into humans causes protein expression, which elicits a protective immune response against Mtb.

**Diagram Description:**

*   **Virus** (hexagon structure) containing **DNA** that **Encodes Antigen protein of Mtb**.

# Modified Vaccinia Ankara 85A
*(handwritten: viral vector)*

A viral vector comprising a recombinant replication deficient modified **vaccinia virus, Ankara (MVA)** that allows insertion of large immunogenic sequences and is efficient at **induction of specific T cell responses**.

MVA expressing **antigen 85A (MVA85A)** was shown to **induce a robust Ag85A-specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses** and protected animals to the same extent as BCG following low-dose aerosol infection.

*(handwritten: Subunit: H56/IC31: ESAT6/Ag85B)*

# Modified Vaccinia Ankara 85A
*(Handwritten: Antigen 85A)*

The vaccine has completed a small non-randomized phase I study to evaluate its safety and immunogenicity in 12 healthy volunteers latently infected with TB (NCT00456183)
It showed that MVA85A is immunogenic in LTBI individuals as well as in BCG vaccinated but Mtb-uninfected individuals

Limitations:
*   Small sample size
*   Heterogenicity of the population
*   The vaccine induced a persistent Ag85A-specific polyfunctional T cell response until week 24 post vaccination. *(Handwritten: (6m))*

To Conclude...

<mark>VPM1002, Vaccae</mark> are the vaccines considered as our nearest candidates to join the BCG vaccine for prevention of disease.

<mark>Therapeutic vaccination</mark> can influence host immune responses.

Given that even in <mark>cured TB patients</mark>, long-term sequelae of disease due to immunopathology is present in a substantial proportion of patients revisiting therapeutic vaccination through the lens of modifying post-cure pathology may offer a new path for using these reagents for treatment of the world's <mark>deadliest bacterial disease</mark>.

# The evolving evidence and experience world-wide



## Nix TB trial
*   6-month BPaL regimen – with oral medicines Bedaquiline, Pretomanid and Linezolid (1200 mg)
*   90% of patients with highly-resistant, treatment intolerant/nonresponsive MDR/RR-TB achieved relapse-free cure status 6 months after end of treatment
*   Linezolid likely responsible for most adverse events and all dose modifications



## ZeNix TB trial
*   6-month BPaL regimen – with Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid (4 arms: diff. dose, duration) led to the recommendation that the **optimal dosing of Lzd is 600 mg daily** offers the best balance in terms of efficacy and safety in Pre-XDR-TB patients above 14 years of age
*   optimal efficacy (**91% success rate**) in highly-resistant, treatment intolerant/ nonresponsive MDR/RR-TB, with possibility of dose reduction in event of toxicity or poor tolerability
*   the Lzd dose modification (i.e., interrupted, reduced, or discontinued) if needed after 9 weeks of treatment duration



## TB PRACTECAL trial
*   Stage 1 – 6-months – 3 arms (BPaL, BPaL+Moxifloxacin, BPaL+Clofazimine)
*   Stage 2 – 6-month BPaLM regimen – with oral medicines Bedaquiline (B), Pretomanid (Pa), Linezolid (L)(600 mg) and Moxifloxacin (M)
*   **favorable efficacy** (treatment success rate 89%) and
*   **safety** (more than 2 times lesser grade >3 adverse events as against in the prevailing standard of care)

# Nix TB AND ZeNix TB

The initial, pivotal trial conducted by the TB Alliance (Nix-TB) was an open-label, single-group study from South Africa which showed that 6 months of BPaL (bedaquiline, pretomanid and linezolid) resulted in favorable outcomes in 90% of patients with XDR-TB and MDR-TB which was non-responsive or treatment intolerant.

However, these astounding success rates came at the cost of considerable toxicity, as the dose of linezolid used in this study was 1200 mg a day.

A follow-up study (ZeNix) by the same group across 11 sites in 4 countries showed that 600 mg of linezolid was an equally effective, but less toxic dose.

Standard Treatment Regimen of Anti TB drugs



# STREAM 2 trial → shorter ≈ longer

The STREAM stage 1 trial showed that a 9-month regimen → Shorter MDR TB Rx for the treatment of rifampicin-resistant tuberculosis was non-inferior to the 20-month 2011 WHO-recommended regimen.

STREAM Stage 2 study, just published, demonstrate that two short BDQ based regimens (one of 6 months including 2 months of injectable kanamycin, and the other, all-oral, of 9 months) were both superior to the longer regimen established to be effective in the earlier STREAM Stage 1 study.

STREAM : Standard Treatment Regimen of Anti-tuberculosis drugs for patients with MDR-TB

**Objective**
To determine Effectiveness, Safety & Tolerability of various doses and duration of Linezolid in combination with Bedaquilline and Pretomanid after 26 weeks of treatment in adults with either Pre-Extensively Drug-Resistant (Pre-XDR) OR Treatment Intolerant / Non-responsive multidrug resistant (MDRnon) Pulmonary Tuberculosis (26m).

**India's experience on use of mBPAL regimen...2**
1200 → 600mg Linezolid

**Methods:**
* Patients were randomly assigned to receive Bdq and Pa for 26 weeks along with
    * Arm 1: Lzd (600mg) daily for 26 weeks
    * Arm 2: Lzd (600mg) for 9 weeks then Lzd (300mg) for 17 weeks
    * Arm 3: Lzd (600mg) for 13 weeks then Lzd (300mg) for 13 weeks (total 26 weeks = 6m)
        * 13 600mg
        * 13 300mg
* Baseline characteristics were comparable in all three arms

**Primary outcome:**
* Proportion of patients with favourable outcomes as sustained cure and treatment completion. Safety of the regimens was also evaluated.

**Interim results (N=125)**
* 56% females, mean age 38 years
* 112/118 (95%) cured at 26 weeks
* Two bacteriological in A2 and one clinical failure (AE) in A3
* Three (2.5%) died compared to 13% in current regimen
* Safety analysis:
    * Most of the adverse events were mild (grade 1) were resolved during treatment
    * AE more in A1 compared to A2 & A3
    * 9/518 (1.7%) were grade 3 adverse events
    * Lower incidence of Lzd associated toxicity in group that had structured reduction to 300mg after 13 weeks
* Sustained treatment success rate expected by March 2024
